title: The Apprentice star accuses bosses of 'sabotaging tasks'
text:
A former contestant of The Apprentice has spoken out (Picture: BBC)

A former contestant on The Apprentice has claimed that producers on the show would ‘sabotage the tasks to make candidates look stupid’.

Aleksandra King, who quit the BBC series back in 2016, alleged that the crew manipulated her team’s stock during a sweet task which led her to step down from participating in the show.

The 41-year-old explained that she and her competitors thoroughly checked their inventory and said: ‘Upon returning, we were shocked to see that not only was there stock missing but that our candy sticks were also cracked.’

She added to the Daily Star: ‘I was conscious this would damage my reputation and addressed it with production at the time stating that I know what they did.’

A spokesperson for The Apprentice told Metro.co.uk: ‘We represent candidates in a fair and balanced light, and everything seen on screen is an accurate portrayal of events.

‘We have rules and guidelines for each task to ensure that tasks are fairly executed for each team.

‘These rules are not a form of sabotage, but instead, ensure that there is a level playing field for all candidates to complete the task.’

Aleksandra, who has reportedly sent a letter to MPs for the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport committee’s inquiry into reality TV, added that The Apprentice hopefuls eat irregular meals and have limited sleep.

She said this is to ‘ensure candidates are physically and mentally weakened.’

‘By the time I made the decision to leave the show I was at the end of my line,’ Aleksandra concluded.

A spokesperson replied: ‘The wellbeing of the candidates that take part in The Apprentice is of paramount importance, and we have a thorough and robust duty of care protocol in place which includes an experienced network of support for all candidates before, during and after filming.’

The Apprentice continues Wednesday at 9pm on BBC One.
